subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: Classic example
author: Ursula Bielski
full_text:
--0-40037113-1198971388=:63775
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Amen!

mllejade <leongbabe@...> wrote:          I agree with you, Ursula, in that there is a fine line between 
objective and subjective reality and that one must somehow synthesize 
the two in digesting the information for oneself. When exchanging 
findings with others, however, I'm always willing to give in that I 
respect those who see images I may not see, or hear voices I may not 
hear, but I will not give to the point of patronization by saying 
that I, too, see that image or hear that voice if, in fact, I don't.

Sharon

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, Ursula Bielski <ursulabielski@...> 
wrote:
>
> I don't know as there are "hundreds" of examples available to the 
public in the way of Luminator photographs, but there are a couple of 
dozen in Macy's book, "Spirit Faces," and yes, many many of them are 
open to wide interpretation, just as our humble recordings are. In 
addition to that majority that make us say, "Come on!{" there are a 
handful that make you say "Hmmmmmmm. . . ." Just like we offer a 
handful of results from our endless recording efforts to try to 
convince the hard-nosed.
> I would think that many would see the Luminator efforts as a 
modern effort at scrying. Everything we do crosses boundaries, and 
my point is that it's really hard to walk the line between trying to 
be scientific and trying to be open. It's really, really hard! But 
if we give in one area, we have to be willing to give in another. 
> Ursula
> 
> 
> Lisby <lisby@...> wrote:
> This is a classic example of the kind of photo that Mark 
thinks shows 
> a spirit extra. To me, clearly, this is the same woman--same hair, 
> same eyes, same mouth, same nose. Again, to me, it looks like a 
> classic long exposure when compared with other known long exposures-
- 
> I've included just of hundreds of examples.
> 
> Ann
>
